title: PCT 46: Wisahketchahk visits his little brother, the skunk
author: Coming-Day

sentences.english: Once upon a time Wisahketchahk with his wife was moving camp.
As usual, he was hungry.
Then at one time, he saw a tipi

sentences.original: êkotah êh-takohtêt, wâpamêw nâpêwa, pêyak iskwêwa owîkimâkaniyiwa.
sentences.text: êkota ê-takohtêt wâpamêw nâpêwa pêyak iskwêwa owîkimâkaniyiwa
sentences.english: When he walked up to the place, we saw a man and a woman, the man's wife.
“Come in, come in!” the other said to him.

sentences.original: hâ, nisîm, itwêw, ôtah êcik ôma êh-ayâyan ?
sentences.english: “Why, Brother,” he cried, “and so this is where you are staying!”
“Yes,” answered the other.
They went in.

sentences.original: hêhêhêy! namoya mistahi ihtakon ka-mîciyahk, itwêyiwa.
sentences.english: “Well, well, well! There isn't much for us to eat,” said the man.
Then they gave him food; they ate.
They stayed there.
At last night came.
“Come, Old Woman, sweep out the tent,” said Wisahketchahk's younger brother;
“My big brother has been going hungry, you know.
Let us call some buffalo,” said he.
Accordingly, she swept.
Then he filled the pipe, and they smoked.
When they had smoked, he took a rattle.
“Now, Big Brother, you too are to sing.”
“Yes!”
Then the other sang, using the rattle.

sentences.original: â, kahkiyaw nikamôwak, piyisk kinwês; piyisk pôyowak;
sentences.text: â kahkiyaw nikamôwak piyisk kinwês piyisk pôyowak
sentences.english: They all sang, for a long time; at last they ceased;
they went to bed; they slept.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahk kîksêpâ, êh-wayawît awa kisêyiniw, kisiwâk wâpamêw mostoswah.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahk kîkisêpâ ê-wayawît awa kisêyiniw kisiwâk wâpamêw mostoswa
sentences.english: In the morning early, when the old man went outside, he saw the buffalo close by.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêw : wâh, nistêsê, ksiwâk ayâwak mostoswak! itwêyiwa, êh-otinâyit sîsîkwanah.
sentences.english: He said, “Hullo, Brother, the buffalo are close by!” and as he spoke, he took up his rattle.

sentences.original: â, nsîm, nîst êtokê nik-êtohtân, itêw.
sentences.english: “Oh, Brother, don't you suppose I could go there, too?” he asked him.
“No,” the other told him, and went out of the tent, to the buffalo-close.

sentences.original: êkotê ê-tohtêyit, âkawâyihk ohci kitâpamêw, kâ-wâpamât skwâhtêmihk êh-nahapiyit ôh ôsîma, êh-nikamoyit.
sentences.text: êkotê ê-itohtêyit âkawâyihk ohci kitâpamêw kâ-wâpamât iskwâhtêmihk ê-nahapiyit ôhi osîma ê-nikamoyit
sentences.english: When the other went there, he watched him from behind something, and there he saw his little brother seat himself and sing.

sentences.original: mayaw êh-pêhtahkik ôki mostoswak, sêmâk pê-sipwêhtêwak, ôhi ksêyiniwah êh-moskîstawâyit.
sentences.text: mayaw ê-pêhtahkik ôki mostoswak sêmâk pê-sipwêhtêwak ôhi kisêyiniwa ê-môskîstawâyit
sentences.english: As soon as those buffalo heard it, at once they started off in that direction, going straight for the old man.

sentences.original: awa kisêyiniw ômis îtwêw : îtawiyaw pimohtêh! itêw ôhi mostoswah.
sentences.text: awa kisêyiniw ômisi itwêw itêw ôhi mostoswa
sentences.english: Then the old man spoke as follows:  “Walk along at both sides!” he said to the buffalo.
And really, they walked past on either side of him, and entered the buffalo-pound.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah acicisiniyiwah ôhi kisêyiniwa, êh-kitâpamât awa wîsahkêcâhk osîmah, êh-pwêkitôyit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa acicisiniyiwa ôhi kisêyiniwa ê-kitâpamât awa wîsahkêcâhk osîma ê-pwêkitoyit
sentences.english: Thereupon that old man got down on all fours with his head to the ground, and, Wisahketchahk all the while watching his younger brother, broke wind.
He killed them all.
He envied his younger brother for what he saw him do.
So the Wisahketchahk went back to the tipi.

sentences.original: êh-apit, kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit osîma, hâ, nistêsê, mistahi êkwah ka-mîcisonânaw; mihcêt nnipahâwak mostoswak, êh-itikot.
sentences.english: As he sat there, his brother cam in, and, “Ho, Big Brother, now we shall eat a plenty; I have killed many buffalo,” he told him.
“Splendid!” said Wisahketchahk;
and the other said to him, “Come, take your knife; let us go do the butchering.”

sentences.original: tâpwê kahkiyaw tohtêwak, ôki mîna iskwêwak.
sentences.text: tâpwê kahkiyaw itohtêwak ôki mîna iskwêwak
sentences.english: So they all went there, the women too.
When he got there, he saw many buffalo lying there.

sentences.original: wah-wînihtâkêwak; kahkiyaw wiyanihêwak; êkwah awatâwak wiyâsah.
sentences.text: wa-wiyanihtâkêwak kahkiyaw wiyanihêwak êkwa âwatâwak wiyâsa
sentences.english: They cleaned one after the other; they cut them all up; then they carried off the meat.
He gave him half the meat;

sentences.original: êkwah mistahi ayâw mîciwin, êkwah owîkimâkanah êy-osîhtâyit kâhkêwakwah.
sentences.text: êkwa mistahi ayâw mîciwin êkwa owîkimâkana ê-osîhtâyit kâhkêwakwa
sentences.english: so now he had plenty of food, and his wife set about making dried meat.
But still he envied the other his way of killing them.
He wanted to go away;

sentences.original: êkwah oyaskinahêw otôspwâkanah, êh-pasikôt, êh-miyât ôh ôsîmah.
sentences.text: êkwa oyaskinahêw otôspwâkana ê-pasikôt ê-miyât ôhi osîma
sentences.english: so he filled his pipe and rose to his feet, and gave it to his little brother.
Wisahketchahk wept;
he spoke as follows: “Little Brother, take pity on me;
I long for you power of killing game in this way,” said Wisahketchahk, weeping.
At last the other said, “Yes,” to him.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah ê-nahapit, ômis îtik : hâw, nistêsê, iyikohk wî-sipwêhtêyinih;
sentences.english: When accordingly he had sat down, the other said to him, “Now, Big Brother, wait until you are ready to leave;

sentences.original: misawâc mêkwâc mistahi kitayânânaw wiyâs, êh-itikot.
sentences.english: for the present we have in any case a great deal of meat,” the other told him.

sentences.original: hâw, nisîm, ôtêh pimohtêwak ntawâsimisak, itêw;
sentences.english: “Well, Little Brother, over yonder my children are walking along,” he told him;
“With reference to this very day, 'In that place I shall see you,' I told them.
So now is when I must leave,” he told him.

sentences.original: nâh, itik owîkimâkanah, mistah ômah wiyâs kitayânânaw; mâka kitawâsimisinawak êkota ka-pêhikonawak.
sentences.english: “Nonsense,” his wife said to him, “Here we have all this meat; after all, our children will wait for us over there.”
“What matter, since my brother is going to give me his hunting-power?

sentences.original: wâpamâyahkwâwi kitawâsimisinawak, êkotê mihcêt nka-nipahâwak mostoswak, itwêw.
sentences.english: When we see our children, I shall kill plenty of buffalo over there,” said he.
“Very well,” his wife answered him.

sentences.original: êkosi ômis îtik osîmah : hâw, nistêsê, kâ-wîh-miyitân ntisi-minahôwin!
sentences.english: Then his younger brother spoke to him as follows:  “Now then, Big Brother, I shall give you my power of killing game in this way!”
Then they left the tipi and walked off to one side.
“There, Brother, sid down here!”
Wisahketchahk sat down.
“Get down on all fours!”
So he crouched down that way;

sentences.original: nêt ôtêh osîmah êkos îsi acicisiniyiwa, ê-kitâpamikot.
sentences.text: nêtê ôtê osîma êkosi isi acicisiniyiwa ê-kitâpamikot
sentences.english: over at this end his brother crouched in the same way, and kept looking at him.
“Big Brother, pull aside your breech-clout!”
He pulled it aside.
“Pull your buttocks like this!”
Then Wisahketchahk stretched them hard;
when he had done it properly, the other broke wind.
At once Wisahketchahk flew up into the air.
Far off he fell; he had a bad fall.

sentences.original: pasikôw, êh-itohtêt, hâw, pêyakwâw, nistêsê! êh-itikot.
sentences.english: He got up and walked back, and, “Fall, once more!” said the other to him.
Now he was afraid of it.
“Come, Big Brother!”
At last he obeyed.

sentences.original: âsay mîna acicisin, âsay mîna êh-pwêkicitikot.
sentences.text: âsay mîna acicisin âsay mîna ê-pwêkicitikot
sentences.english: Again he crouched down, and again the other broke wind at him.
Again he fell far.
Then for a long time he lay there as though dead.
Then at last he rose to his feet, and went to leave.
“There, come, Old Woman, let us go.”
They departed.

sentences.original: wâhyaw êy-îhtâcik, hâw, nôtokêsiw, matwân_cî tâpwê êh-miyit kaskitêw ? itwêw;
sentences.english: When they were far from there, “Well, Old Woman, can it be that he really has given me the power?” said he;
“Suppose I take a trial shot at this grove of trees.”
“Don't!” his wife said to him;
“You will waste it.
Didn't you say we were to get our food from it?”
“Well, perhaps he was trying to fool me.
Do let me make a trial shot.
Undeterred, he made a trial shot with that grove of trees as his target.
He knocked over all the trees.

sentences.original: kâh, tâpw ês âni nimiyik ominahôwin nisîm!
sentences.english: “What do you think of that! So my little brother did really give me his way of killing game!”
Then he set out again, as before.

sentences.original: namoya wâhyaw êy-ihtât, kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit asiniyah.
sentences.text: namôya wâhyaw ê-ihtât kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit asiniya
sentences.english: He had not gone far, when he saw a big stone.

sentences.original: êhâ, nôtokêsiw, mâhcih nka-kotahâskwân, êh-itwêt, êkâ wiyah! itik owîkimâkanah.
sentences.english: “Hey, Old Woman, suppose I do some target-shooting,” he said, and “Do not!” his wife told him.
Over he protest he broke wind at the stone.
He knocked it bodily into the air;
the stone flew to pieces.
“Well, Old Woman, let us pitch camp;
I am hungry,” he said to her.
“What are we to eat?” she asked him.
“Let us build a buffalo-pound; we shall call some buffalo,” he told her.
“Very well!”
They pitched camp.

sentences.original: ê-kîsi-mânokêcik, êkwah taw-osîhtâwak pîhtokahân, êkwah ê-tipiskâyik, êh-nikamocik, êh-ntômâcik mostoswah.
sentences.text: ê-kîsi-mânokêcik êkwa ta-osîhtâwak pîhtokahân êkwa ê-tipiskâyik ê-nikamocik ê-nitomâcik mostoswa
sentences.english: When they had set up their tipi, they went about building the pound, and them, after dark, they sang to call the buffalo.
Early in the morning he saw the buffalo.

sentences.original: êkwah sipwêhtêw, iskwâhtêmihk ê-nahapit awa wîsahkêcâhk, êkwah êh-nikamot, îtawiyaw pimohtêk!
sentences.text: êkwa sipwêhtêw iskwâhtêmihk ê-nahapit awa wîsahkêcâhk êkwa ê-nikamot
sentences.english: Then he set out, and sat down in the entrance-way, this Wisahketchahk, and began to sing, “Walk along at either side!”
When he sang thus, as soon as the buffalo heard him, they started running toward him.

sentences.original: kisiwâk êh-ayâyit, tâwâskikan! êh-itwêt, tâwikipayihik mostoswah.
sentences.english: When they were near, he said, “Square in the chest!” and the buffalo ran right into him.
For a long time they trampled him out of his senses.
Then his wife saw him.

sentences.original: êh-kitâpamikot owîkimâkanah, êy-ispahtâyit, pîkonamiyiwa om ôpîhtokahân.
sentences.text: ê-kitâpamikot owîkimâkana ê-ispahtâyit pîkonamiyiwa ôma opîhtokahân
sentences.english: When she saw him, she ran there, and broke down his enclosure.
All the buffalo ran out.
Only then he got up, having returned to his senses.
Then he threw himself down on all fours and broke wind.

sentences.original: nama kêkway nipahêw; âyisk kîh-mêstinam kâ-kotahâskwêt.
sentences.text: nama kêkway nipahêw ayisk kî-mêstinam kâ-kotahâskwêt
sentences.english: He killed nothing; for he had wasted it in target-shooting.

sentences.original: atimo-kisêyiniw! itik owîkimâkanah, êkâ kêkway êh-nipahtât, êh-kîhkâmikot.
sentences.text: itik owîkimâkana êkâ kêkway ê-nipahtât ê-kîhkâmikot
sentences.english: “Dog of an old man!” his wife said to him, when he killed nothing, and she began to scold him.
“Well, Old Woman, please, do you run back;
run to my little brother's;
go ask him for some of that game-killing power that he gave me, so that we may use it to get food.”
So the old woman went back.

sentences.original: nêtê êh-takohtêt, hâw, nîtim, mistah êh-ma-mâyînikêt kistês, êh-mêstinahk kâ-kîh-miyat kit-ôh-minahot, êh-kâ-kotahâskwêt.
sentences.english: When she arrived over yonder, “Well, Brother-in-Law, I have come because your brother, who always makes a bad mess of things, has used up in target-shooting that which you gave him for killing game.

sentences.original: êkwah mînah kinwêsk nipahik mostoswah, êh-itwêt, êh-itwêt.
sentences.english: And, besides, the buffalo knocked him silly for a long time, because he said, ‘Square in the chest!’ and then he said, ‘It was a slip of the tongue.’
‘Just you now go there; go ask my brother for some of his way of killing game,’ he told me, and that is why I have come here.”

sentences.original: âhag, nîtim, ka-miyitin nîswâw kit-ôh-minahoyan, itêw; âh, âstam!
sentences.english: “Very well, Sister-in-Law, I will give you wherewith twice to kill game,” he told her;
They went out of the tent.
“So then, Sister-in-Law, get down on all fours here!”
Then he too got down on all fours.
“Stretch out your buttocks like this!”

sentences.original: tâpwê êkosi êh-tôtahk, êh-pwêkicitikot, wâhyaw pahkisin.
sentences.text: tâpwê êkosi ê-tôtahk ê-pwêkicitikot wâhyaw pahkisin
sentences.english: And really, when she did that way, and he broke wind at her, far off she fell to the ground.

sentences.original: kîhtwâm mîna êkos êh-tôtâkot, êh-pwêkicitikot, kinwêsê kinwêsk nipahisin awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.text: kîhtwâm mîna êkosi ê-tôtâkot ê-pwêkicitikot kinwês kinwêsk nipahisin awa nôtokêsiw
sentences.english: When he did it to here a second time and broke wind at her, for a long, long time the old woman lay senseless.
When she came back to life, she went back.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêyit, awa wîsahkêcâhk, niwîkimâkan, kimiyik cî ?
sentences.english: When she arrived, Wisahketchahk, “Wife, did he give you any?”
“Dog of an old man, and so it is a difficult thing, as it turns out!” she answered him.
Then they build up the buffalo-pound which she had pulled down.

sentences.original: êh-kîsihtâcik, êkwah êh-tipiskâyik, êkosi kâ-nikamocik, ê-ntômâcik mostoswah.
sentences.text: ê-kîsihtâcik êkwa ê-tipiskâyik êkosi kâ-nikamocik ê-nitomâcik mostoswa
sentences.english: When they had got it in shape, and night came, they sang to call the buffalo.

sentences.original: tâpwê ê-nipâcik, êh-wâpahk, kîksêpâ, kâ-wâpamât mostoswah.
sentences.text: tâpwê ê-nipâcik ê-wâpahk kîkisêpâ kâ-wâpamât mostoswa
sentences.english: And really, when they had slept, early the next morning, there he saw the buffalo.
Then the old woman went over there.
Then she sang.
“Walk along at either side!” were her words.
Thereupon they went into the pound.
Then the old woman got down on all fours and broke wind.
She killed all the buffalo.
Wisahketchahk was very glad.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-awatâcik wiyâs, hâw, nôtokêsiw, pakâhtâkohkê.
sentences.english: Then, when they carried in the meat, “Well, Old Woman, boil it in the kettle.
When we have eaten, we shall prepare jerked meat,” he told his wife.
“Yes,” said the old woman.
And so, when they had eaten, they made jerked meat.
He envied his wife the way she had killed the buffalo.

sentences.original: êkwah isîhtâw kâhkêwakwa awa wîsahkêcâhk, êh-atih-akotât mistikohk.
sentences.text: êkwa isîhtâw kâhkêwakwa awa wîsahkêcâhk ê-ati-akotât mistikohk
sentences.english: And so Wisahketchahk prepared dried meat, hanging it on a tree.

sentences.original: piyisk ê-tipiskâyik, hahâw, êkâya nipâh, nôtokêsiw; kakwê-kîsihtâh kiwiyâsima, itêw.
sentences.english: When at last it grew dark, “Now, Old Woman, do not go to sleep; try to finish preparing your meats,” he told her.
And so that old woman spent the whole night curing meat.
At last she was sleepy.
“Don't go to sleep, Wife!” he told her.
Finally the old woman fell asleep.

sentences.original: waniskâ, niwîkimâkan! kipânisâwâ! iyât-îtâcih, namoya pêkopayiyiwa; nipâyiwa.
sentences.english: Even when he said to her “Get up, Wife! Don't forget your meat-curing!” she did not wake up; she was asleep.
“I will steal it from her,” he thought, meaning that with which she had killed the buffalo.

sentences.original: piyisk oskotâkâsiyiw owîkimâkanah ohpinamwêw, itah k-ôh-pwêkitoyit êkotah êh-itâpit.
sentences.text: piyisk oskotâkâsiyiw owîkimâkana ohpinamwêw ita kâ-ôh-pwêkitoyit êkota ê-itâpit
sentences.english: Finally he lifted up his wife's petticoat, and looked at whence she broke wind.

sentences.original: kâ-wâpahtahk ôma k-ôh-pwêkitôyit, êkwah miscikos otinam, ê-wih-otâskwahamowât, ê-wîh-kimotamawât.
sentences.text: kâ-wâpahtahk ôma kâ-ôh-pwêkitoyit êkwa miscikos otinam ê-wî-otâskwahamawât ê-wî-kimotamawât
sentences.english: When he had caught sight of that from which she broke wind, he took a little stick, meaning to take it from her by means of the stick and to steal it from her.
Just as he began to twitch the stick, she woke up and broke wind.

sentences.original: mêtoni wâhyaw ihtakocin awa wîsahkêcâhk, ê-pistahokot owîkimâkanah.
sentences.text: mêtoni wâhyaw itakocin awa wîsahkêcâhk ê-pistahokot owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Off and away, to a great distance, Wisahketchahk went flying, when his wife thus accidentally shot him.
There he fell to the ground, for a long time he lay as if dead.

sentences.original: atimo-kisêyiniw kâ-môhcôwit, kâ-wiyakihtât! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.english: “Dog of an old man, crazy fool, to waste it like that!” cried the old woman.

sentences.original: êkwah wîsahkêcâhk omis îtwêw : ê-kîh-itisk cî nisîm ?
sentences.english: Then Wisahketchahk said, “‘When your husband is in the act of getting up, use him as a target for your shots,’ is that what my brother told you to do?”
“No, you are crazy, that is all,” his wife answered him.

sentences.original: ayah ês ôhi sikâkwah ôhi kâ-mâh-miyikocik ta-minahocik.
sentences.text: aya êsa ôhi sikâkwa ôhi kâ-mâh-miyikocik ta-minahocik
sentences.english: It appears that he was the Skunk, he who gave them the power of killing game.
And so this is the end of this sacred story.
